Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: What is the Fate of a Silent Forest? The Importance of Avian Seed Dispersal and Herbivore Control for Tropical Forest Community Structure
Award.AbstractNarration:
Birds in forests eat insects and fruit, and move seeds throughout the forest (seed dispersal), but how important are these actions for forest structure? The research addresses this question on the island of Guam (where birds are absent because the non-native brown tree snake has eliminated them) and the nearby islands of Rota, Tinian and Saipan (with native birds remaining). The research uses experiments and observations to determine the importance of birds for seed dispersal and pest control (i.e. reduction of plant-eating insects) for ten common tree species that vary in characteristics such as seed size, manner in which seeds are dispersed, and growth rate.

The research addresses basic ecological questions, including whether seed dispersal is important for tree species diversity and whether birds control forest insect populations. If birds are critical to the functioning of a healthy forest, then the current global decline in birds may lead to the breakdown of forests worldwide. This research is additionally important because insects are the largest pests to working forests, which provide billions of dollars to the global economy each year. Thus, the results from this work will inform management from local to global scales. Finally, several educational programs will target local Pacific Islander high school and college students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
What is the fate of a silent forest?

What happens when forests lose their native birds? Increasingly, human actions are causing bird populations to decline, but the implications of this bird loss for forest health and functioning are not certain. Since birds move seeds throughout the forest (seed dispersal) and eat insects that consume tree seeds and seedlings, silent forests may function differently than do forests with healthy bird populations.

We sought to understand the importance of birds for forest function by comparing forests on the island of Guam, where birds are absent because the invasive brown tree snake has eliminated them, to the nearby islands of Rota, Tinian and Saipan which have relatively healthy native bird populations. Specifically, the research team set out to quantify the importance of birds for seed dispersal and the influence of birds on insect pest populations and plant health. This was accomplished with observations and experiments on 14 different forest sites across the four islands.

These research activities led to the following conclusions. First, fruit-eating birds play a critical role in the life cycle of several native tree species. Specifically, the consumption of fruits by birds enhances seed germination for at least two tree species. Birds also move seeds away from parent trees, which increases survival of seedlings for 4 of the 5 species we tested, presumably because seedlings can escape high disease and predation pressure associated with parent trees. Moreover, the regeneration of degraded forests is likely to be slower without fruit-eating birds; degraded forests on Guam receive no native seeds from nearby forests, whereas many native seeds landed in degraded forests on Saipan. In the second part of our research, we investigated the role of insectivorous birds and surprisingly found that insect pressures on forest trees are not higher on Guam than on islands with birds. Possibly, insect consumption by spiders compensates for bird loss. Consistent with this possibility is that spider numbers have sky rocketed in Guam’s forests. In all, results suggest that silent forests function very differently from forests with birds, primarily through the loss of seed handling and dispersal activities by birds.

In addition to the scientific findings described above, the research has also contributed to management, education and outreach. Our research team has shared our results through presentations to local and federal natural resource agencies. Over 20 undergraduate students or recent graduates were involved in this research, including five students who completed independent research projects (several of which are leading to scientific publications). At the K-12 level, the research team developed educational materials in collaboration with 5 teachers (4 from schools in the Mariana Islands), and distributed these materials to every public and most private high schools in the Mariana Islands. In addition, we taught a 15-day Island Ecology Field Course for 14 students from three universities in the Mariana Islands. Finally, results of this research have been communicated to the general public in the Mariana Islands and across the globe through public presentations, and interviews for radio, newspapers and books.
